reviews.title: Try the condos!
reviews.text: For our second stay at this motel, we chose one of the their three condos, situated on a hill overlooking the motel main building. The views of Big Bend National Park and the Chisos mountains are absoultely stunning - there's a saying in Terlingua that it's the only place where you face east to watch the sunset; do it and you'll realise why!

reviews.title: Hard Boiled?
reviews.text: The condos are well-equipped and comfortable - bathroom and kitchen well-supplied with towels, cleaning materials etc. The bedroom was beautfully furnished, and the sofa-bed in the living area also very comfortable. Satellite TV but no phone. Motel staff very friendly and happy to reccommend where to go to eat/listen to music etc. We got the feeling work was not quite complete - the area at the back of the condos is not cultivated, and we would have appreciated a small garden area there. Also, we had to park our car right in front of the 'view', which was a pity! Terlingua is not over-endowed with higher-end accommodation, and if you want a touch more comfort, these condos are a great bet.

reviews.title: Clean motel, COLD Air Conditioning
reviews.text: The town itself is a joy - eccentric without being over-the-top, great eating places (don't miss breakfast at the Big Bend Motor Inn or dinner at the Starlight), and the local music scene is buzzing. If you want to be really near the action of Big Bend and still have some entertainment in the evening, this is the ideal place.

reviews.title: Very Friendly Folks!
reviews.text: During the Spring of 2002 a number of us rented several "condos". After noticing a "Bad Egg" smell, from one of the units, we complained to the office. After some time, we investigated our selves what it could be. The smell was getting worse. It was discovered that the pilot was not lit on the hot water heater and gas was leaking into the room. Thanks goodness nobody got cooked! The other problem we had with another unit was a tub that didn't drain. With nasty, smelly water pooled in the tub for the weekend, we had no choice but to use a neighbors shower during our 4 day stay. The management did nothing to solve the problem. However, the rooms were nice and I might give them a second chance. Who knows, maybe the have a different staff by now.

reviews.title: A Lucky Find in Texas' Big Bend
reviews.text: got there late, not a problem. walking distance from 3 restaurants, an underground steakhouse called La Kiva, an outdoor diner called the Hungry Javalina, and Tivos Mexican restaurant. All good. La Kiva has live music. Everything is affordable.Motel is simple and attractive. we stayed in a room with 2 beds and TV. 105 degrees outside, 72 inside. COLD A/C. VERY NICE.

Stayed at the Chisos Mountain Co Motel with the family for a few nights while exploring the Big Bend region. Room was inexpensive, basic, and clean. They’re basically spruced up pre-fab cabins planted in the desert, but it met our needs. The best aspect of this lodging is it is convenient to the restaurants and shops of Terlingua yet still an easy drive into the park. The region of Terlingua/Study Butte is a bit bizarre, but a fun place to spend a few days. Unless you’re camping or really want to stay in the park, this is a good option.
reviews.title: Basic, but met our needs

reviews.text: Maybe all the residents of this town were cranky because the heat index was off the charts for this time of year, or maybe we had a substitute who checked us in, but considering that we were one of the few rooms booked, you would think we would be greated accordingly and welcomed to Terlingua. Not so. You would think these cabins were the Taj Mahal the way the manager cranked out the rules of our stay. We got the impression that our business was not wanted when we realized that we were the only cabin booked and the other motel rooms were at 5 percent capacity, so it would have been a nice touch if the manager had just turned on the window a/c unit so we would check in to a cabin that had not been baking at 100 plus all day before we checked in. This is a small town, but the service here did not reflect it at all. Very old, very basic accomodations with plastic chairs falling down the hill and junky cars accumulating here and there. It doesn't even have a restaurant to make it somehow make sense. There are better places to stay than this.....
reviews.title: Why stay here?
Clean and friendly
reviews.text: A nice place to stay at a good price

reviews.title: Chisos Mining Co. Motel at Easter Egg Valley
reviews.text: We chose this motel after finding out that the lodge in Big Bend Na. Park was full. Actually located closer to the town of Study Butte. We had the yellow cabin and it was large, clean and comforable. 2 dbl beds, 1 twin bed and a full kitchen (that we didn't use). There was no phone or tv in this cabin (we knew that when we reserved it) but what do you need a tv for when you can sit outside and watch roadrunners, jackrabbits and a beautiful star filled sky (btw you look east to watch the sunset). The staff was very friendly and helpful as were most of the locals that we spoke to. We will stay here on our next trip to Big Bend.

reviews.title: friendly, clean serviceable motel
reviews.text: I had hoped to get a room in the Chisos Lodge in Big Bend Park over the New Year's holiday, but it was fully booked, so I looked at the listings here on Trip Advisor and made a reservation at Chisos Mining Company instead. What a great outcome. Room was inexpensive (abt $55 for a room with two beds and private bath), basic, clean, well-maintained. Motel staff was friendly, helpful with advice. Best of all, it was convenient to all the restaurants and shops of Terlingua (and Study Butte). What a fun, friendly community -- lively restaurants (Starlight Theater, Tivo's, Roadrunner Deli), good music, interesting stores, and really some of the friendliest people I've met. Ultimately, my visit to Big Bend was really enhanced by spending each night and morning with these fun, friendly people; turns out I'm really glad I wasn't able to get a reservation at the Lodge in the Park, because I'm sure I would have stayed there each night (rather then drive out the 20-miles or so to get to Study Butte and Terlingua). And then I'd have missed out on what was a really great part of a fantastic trip to Big Bend.
